attributes.body: Are you inquiring about your own data use, or about data use by someone else?
attributes.label: Q1
attributes.explanation: Somebody else’s data use (please note: there are some questions you might not be able to answer; you will be able to get an idea of the data use’s public value, however it may not be as accurate)

choices.body: My own data use (or data use by the entity that I represent)
Somebody else’s data use (please note: there are some questions you might not be able to answer; you will be able to get an idea of the data use’s public value, however it may not be as accurate)

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the data user? (tick up to two)
attributes.label: Q2
attributes.explanation: Who will be using the data? If you are unsure or if more than two categories apply, please specify via the “Other” option.
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: As our assessment of public value includes underlying motivations, a privately owned company will be less likely, all things being equal, to produce value for the public (-1) than entities committed to the public good  (+1). Users of our tool  can specify a different or multiple categories via the “Other” option, however as this is an unknown, it is scored at 0.

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the primary activity of the data user? (tick up to two)
attributes.label: Q3
attributes.explanation:
This question refers to the primary activity of the data user. If the primary activity can best be explained by a separate category (or across two or more categories), please specify via the “None of the above” option. If you are unsure, please select “I don’t know.”

Note: Basic research seeks to expand fundamental knowledge and understand underlying principles. Applied research tries to solve practical problems and develop real-world applications.
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: As our assessment of public value includes underlying motivations, a privately owned company will be less likely, all things being equal, to produce value for the public (-1) than entities committed to the public good  (+1). Users of our tool  can specify a different or multiple categories via the “Other” option, however as this is an unknown, it is scored at 0.

attributes.body: What is the data user’s primary source of funding? (tick up to two)
attributes.label: Q4
attributes.explanation:
This question aims to capture how the data user finances its operations. Data users that hold comparatively higher financial resources are held to a higher standard regarding its ability to limit risks and maximise benefits of its data use.  

If none of the provided options are applicable, please specify via the "None of the above" option. If you are unsure, please select "I don't know.”
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Larger organisations have a higher standard to attain in terms of public value when compared to smaller and medium sized organisations, as they have comparatively more resources (financial, staffing etc.).

choices.body: Predominantly financed through income from own activities or parent/partner company
Predominantly financed by governmental organisations (national or international)
Predominantly financed by way of large donations
Predominantly financed by way of small donations
Predominantly financed by a political party

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the data user's public reporting requirements? (tick up to two)
attributes.label: Q5
attributes.explanation:
This question aims to understand the frequency and form with which the data usershares information about its activities with the public. The more frequent and the more extensive the reports, the higher the data users transparency and the higher, in turn, the public value created.

If none of the provided options are applicable, please select "None of the above" and specify your unique reporting requirements. If you are unsure, please select "I don't know."
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: In order to ensure trust and enable informed decisions by the public, data use with a high public value tends to be undertaken in a way that is transparent to the public.

choices.body: Annual report on key financials to financial institution
Annual public report on activities to government
Annual non-public report on activities to the funder (or other entities)

metadata.feedback: if the data user had public reporting requirements in place related to data use

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the data user's legal obligations to provide information about its data use activities to the public? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q6
attributes.explanation:
In many jurisdictions public actors need to disclose information when someone files a Freedom of Information (FOI) request. For data users that do not fall within the scope of FOIs (e.g. privately owned businesses), their track record in providing information when requested by citizens or public bodies is taken into account. 

If none of the provided options are applicable, select "None of the above" and specify your unique reporting requirements. If you are unsure, choose "I don't know.”
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data use with a high public value tends to be undertaken in a way that is transparent to the public. In many jurisdictions public actors need to disclose information when someone files a Freedom of Information (FOI) request. Data users that do not fall within the scope of FOIs (e.g. privately owned businesses) are less accountable for their activities to the public (-3).

choices.body: No legal options to compel disclosure of information about data use activities to the public beyond civil or criminal proceedings (e.g., as a result of GDPR obligations)
Can be legally compelled to disclose information about its data use activities (e.g., via freedom of information laws)

metadata.feedback: if the data user could be legally compelled to disclose information about data use activities to the public (beyond civil and criminal proceedings)

attributes.body: Does the data user have a procedure in place to respond to public requests for information on its activities (e.g. freedom of information requests, other legal obligations, or voluntarily)? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q7
attributes.explanation:
This question assesses the data user’s history of responding to requests to provide information to the public on its activities. A track record of rejecting or selectively responding to information requests will reduce the public value of an instance of data use as it does not signal a commitment to transparency, while a record of responding to all information requests will increase it.

If none of the provided options are applicable, please specify via the "None of the above" option. If you are unsure, please select "I don't know.”
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Whether or not the data user responds to public requests for information matters when assessing public value. Having a procedure in place is more likely to lead to data use with a high public value, due to a lack of public accountability (+2). Having no procedure is less likely to lead to public value (-2). None of the above may for example refer to a new data user who has not yet received any information requests (0).

choices.body: Procedure in place to respond to public requests for information
No procedure in place to respond to public requests for information

metadata.feedback: if the data user complied (better) with information requests regarding data use

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the data user's motivation for the data use? (tick as many as necessary)
attributes.label: Q8
attributes.explanation:
This question aims at capturing the user’s motivation for the data use. For example, data use aimed at improving medical treatments is of high value to the public, provided that risks are minimised. 

If none of the provided options are applicable, select "None of the above" and specify the motivation underlying the data use in question. If you are unsure, please select "I don't know.”
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Advancing scientific research, improving medical treatments, combating climate change and combating inequality are all widely-agreed upon goals for society. Therefore, data use which aims to progress towards these goals will likely be of a higher public value (+2). Similarly, improving public services creates value for the public. While data use which is motivated by commercial profit or increasing revenue does not inherently reduce or increase public value, it is less likely to lead to high public value data uses (-1).

metadata.feedback: if the motivation for the data use went beyond generating commercial profits, and prioritised the collective good

attributes.body: Is it plausible to assume that the data use will benefit people in low and middle income countries (LMICs)? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q9
attributes.explanation:
This question aims at understanding whether the applicant has a track record in expanding the range of beneficiaries of its data use to individuals and/or communities in low and middle-income countries (LMICs, or “the Global South”). Multinational corporations frequently generate considerable profits in high-income countries from digital activity in LMICs while paying no tax there which adversely impacts the public value they generate. Data use which helps reduce global inequality by ensuring benefits are shared equally will be of higher public value. 

“Some track record” indicates a few instances of ensuring benefits of data use are felt by individuals and/or communities in LMICs. A “strong track record’ indicates a consistent and sustained generation of benefits in LMICs. . If none of the provided options are applicable, select "None of the above" and specify the data user’s record of distributing benefits to LMICs. If you are unsure, please select "I don't know.”
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data use which helps reduce global inequality by ensuring benefits are shared equitably will be of higher public value. Data use which will plausibly benefit people in lower and middle income countries (LMICs) receives a higher score (+2). No plausibility scores lower (-2), as the data use is less likely to contribute to reducing global inequality.

choices.body: Data use will plausibly benefit people in LMICs
Data use will not plausibly benefit people in LMICs

metadata.feedback: if the data user had previously ensured that their data use benefits people in low and middle-income countries (LMICs)

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the track record of the data user in strengthening the benefits for marginalised groups? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q10
attributes.explanation:
Certain marginalised groups are afforded special protection under anti-discrimination laws. The German Constitution (Basic Law), for instance, prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex, gender, origin, ethnicity, language, belief, religious and political views, and disability (Article 3 Basic Law). This question aims to assess if the likelihood that a given data use will benefit such groups. Data use which helps reduce inequality and which benefits these groups will be of a higher public value. This question should be answered in line with those groups protected in the relevant jurisdiction or, if inapplicable, in international Human Rights law.  

“Some track record” indicates a few instances of strengthening the benefits for marginalised groups. A “strong track record’ indicates consistent and sustained efforts to ensure the benefits of data use are felt by such groups. If you are unsure, please select "I don't know.”
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data use which helps reduce inequality and which benefits groups protected by anti-discrimination laws will be of a higher public value. A strong track record (i.e., consistent and sustained efforts) receives a higher score (+2) than “some track record” (i.e., some instances) (+1). No track record scores lower (-2), as the data use is less likely to contribute to reducing inequality.

choices.body: No track record of  strengthening benefits for groups that are granted protection by way of anti-discrimination laws
Some track record of strengthening benefits for groups that are granted protection by way of anti-discrimination laws
Strong track record of strengthening benefits for groups that are granted protection by way of anti-discrimination laws

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the data use’s benefits for future generations? (tick up to two)
attributes.label: Q11
attributes.explanation:
Future generations are likely to suffer from inequities in the distribution of wealth and income, as well as water scarcity, global warming and migration. Data use that serves a growing societal need, or is likely to benefit future generations in other ways, will have a higher public value. 

If you are unsure, please select "I don't know.”
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Public value in data solidarity is greater if benefits will foreseeably increase in the future, and for future generations. Data use that serves a growing societal need and is likely to benefit future generations in other ways, receives a higher score in this category (1, 2) than data use that does not (1).

choices.body: Benefits primarily cover issues of current and future relevance
Benefits primarily cover issues of relevance for future generations
Benefits are likely to increase in the future

metadata.feedback: if the data user ensured that their data use also benefits future generations

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the type(s) of foreseeable risk to (any) individuals or groups coming from the data use? (tick as many as necessary)
attributes.label: Q12
attributes.explanation:
A key component of assessing the public value of data use is the (foreseeable) risk to individuals or groups, both directly and indirectly. Note that this is not an exhaustive list of potential risk categories. Please use the “Other” option to specify additional risks. Examples of the above include: 

Financial Risk: Sensitive financial data (e.g., bank details, tax information etc.) carries a financial risk to data subjects. An indirect financial risk would be individuals denied insurance or loan applications on the basis of predictions made via the data use. 

Health risk: If data use involves managing health records for example, there is a risk that mishandling data could lead to misdiagnosis or incorrect medical treatment, potentially causing physical harm to individuals. Data misuse can also risk the mental health of individuals.

Informational Risk: Informational risk is the potential for harm from disclosure of information about an identified individual. All sensitive personal data falls under this category, as well as anonymised data which can be conceivably re-identified. 

Political Risk: Data that includes sensitive political indicators (e.g., voting preference, party affiliation, union membership) carries a political risk if they are mishandled or misused. 

Social Risk: If the data use risks the social well-being of individuals or communities, and/or includes sensitive social descriptors, such as sexual orientation.
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: A key component of assessing the public value of data use is the (foreseeable) risk to individuals or groups, both directly and indirectly. Note that although risks will impact the public value score negatively and are measured cumulatively here, this may be offset if sufficient harm mitigation measures are in place (Q16-21).

choices.feedback: if the data use posed lower financial risk to people
if the data use posed lower physical risk to people
if the data use posed lower informational risk to people
if the data use posed lower political risk to people
if the data use posed lower social risk to people
if the data use posed fewer other risks (beyond those listed) to any individuals or groups

attributes.body: Independent of the type of risk, how likely is it that the risk will materialise and create harm? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q13

attributes.body: Does the data user take measures to limit the negative impact of their data use on the natural environment (e.g., using renewable energy sources)? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q14
attributes.explanation:
Data use which in which the impact on the environment is limited will be of higher public value. 

Relevant aspects here are: does energy used to store and process the data come from fully renewable sources? Does the data use in itself further climate protection (e.g. climate research?). If you are unsure, please select "I don't know."
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data use which has a positive impact on the environment is of higher public value, as it contributes to the widely-shared goal of protecting the environment and mitigating climate change. The weights are +/- 5, as data use which impacts the environment is more likely to have a significant impact on individuals and communities.

choices.body: No measures to limit environmental impact
Some measures to limit environmental impact
Extensive measures to limit environmental impact

metadata.feedback: if the negative environmental impacts of the data use were lower

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the possible elevated risks for marginalised groups ? An example for financial risk would be a refused loan application due to being a member of an ethnic minority group (tick one)
attributes.label: Q15
attributes.explanation:
In most jurisdictions, certain groups in society are afforded special protection under anti-discrimination laws. The German Constitution (Basic Law) for instance prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex, gender, origin, ethnicity, language, belief, religious and political views, and disability (Article 3 Basic Law). Adverse effects on groups who are afforded special protection under the law may also be generated incidentally and unintended (such as a loan application being denied).  This question should be answered in line with those groups protected in the relevant jurisdiction or, if inapplicable, in international Human Rights law.  

This question aims to assess the foreseeable risk of an instance of data use for such groups. The risk is "elevated" as it is impossible to remove all risk.
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data use which carries risks (direct or indirect) for groups  given special protection by law is much less likely to generate public value without significant harm mitigation measures in place (-5). Data use which entails no foreseeable risk scores “neutral”  (0).

choices.body: Data use foreseeably entails elevated risk for protected groups
Data use foreseeably entails no elevated risk for protected groups

metadata.feedback: if the data use did not entail possible risks for groups afforded special protection under the law

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the information given by the data user to the public about the risks of their data use? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q16
attributes.explanation: Has the data user informed the public about risks related to their data use  in an accessible way (i.e. is it understandable to a person with limited technical knowledge?)
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data use in which potential risks are openly and transparently communicated prior to commencement will be of higher public value (2), as it allows individuals and communities to make informed decisions. Communication only after the commencement of data use contributes to a lower public value score (-1), as the public is unable to make the same informed decisions. Data use in which no information is provided to the public scores even lower (-2), as there is no chance for informed decision making.

choices.feedback: if the orgnisation provided more information about risks of its data use to the public

choices.body: Information about risks provided to the public at some point during the data use
choices.feedback: if the data user informed the public of any risks prior to the commencement of data use

choices.body: Information about risks provided to the public prior to commencement of data use

attributes.body: Has the data user taken steps to limit the likelihood that the data use creates negative, unintended consequences? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q17
attributes.explanation: This question concerns the risk of dual use. Dual use, in this instance, refers to the potential for data to be misused by a third party for unintended or malicious ends. For example, medical data collected for research could be de-anonymised and used for targeted advertising, or data collected for a consumer survey could be used for illegal phishing scams. A useful question that can guide thinking is which other uses come to mind when examining the data user’s planned data use, how many are there and how likely are they?
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data use which is likely to lead to negative unintended consequences has a lower score (-4) as it poses foreseeable risks to the public. The risk is reduced (0) if steps have been taken to limit this.

choices.body: Steps have been taken to limit negative unintended consequences
No steps have been taken to limit negative unintended consequences

metadata.feedback: if there were steps taken to limit the likelihood that the data use creates negative, unintended consequences

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the data user's way of assessing risk? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q18
attributes.explanation: This question aims to capture whether the data user routinely assesses risks emerging from their data use, and the format in which such assessment is conducted.
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Data users which have no risk assessments in place are less likely to discover problems before they negatively impact individuals and communities (and therefore public value) (-1). Ad-hoc assessments may discover some but miss others (0), whereas a mandatory risk assessment is much more likely to protect the public from significant undue harm, therefore increasing the public value score (1).

choices.body: Mandatory risk assessment (for each data use)

metadata.feedback: if the data user had a (better) risk assessment in place

attributes.body: If there is a risk assessment procedure in place, how are its results used? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q19
attributes.explanation: This question aims to capture the format in which findings from potential risk assessments inform the activities of the data user. For instance, whether data use may only proceed ahead after having responded to/included the findings of the risk assessment or the findings of the risk assessment (strategic actions), or whether no such procedures are in place.
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: A risk assessment process which results in actions (i.e., harm mitigation) is likely to reduce risk to individuals and communities and therefore scores relatively high (2). Risk assessments that only result in information (e.g., non-binding recommendations) scores slightly lower (1).

metadata.feedback: if findings from your risk assessment resulted in strategic actions

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe those involved in the process of assessing risks? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q20
attributes.explanation:
This question captures the background of the persons involved in any risk assessment. A person who is familiar with ethics may highlight and be aware of specific risks entailed in a specific instance of data use, thereby reducing overall risk and increasing its public value. Consulting those with a knowledge of data ethics increases the likelihood of as many risks as possible being included in the course of the risk assessment. Other professionals (e.g., lawyers, computer scientists) can also highlight important issues that pertain to public value. 

If you are unsure, please specify via the “None of the above” option.
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: A person who is familiar with ethics may be particularly well placed to highlight and suggest responses emerging from a specific instance of data use, thereby reducing overall risk and increasing its public value (4). Consulting those with a knowledge of data ethics increases the likelihood of as many risks as possible being included in the course of the risk assessment. Other professionals (legal experts, data scientists) will also be able to highlight specific issues (2).

choices.body: Trained ethicists are not included in the risk assessment
Trained ethicists are included in the risk assessment
Other professionals (e.g. legal, data) involved in risk assessment

metadata.feedback: if the risk assessment included individuals with specific ethics training and expertise

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the process of harm monitoring? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q21
attributes.explanation: This question aims to capture whether the data user routinely monitors harm emerging from their data use. For example, if a company uses personal data obtained from its website to improve its service, does it continually (i.e. regularly) monitor and review potential harms to any individuals or communities affected by this data use?
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Monitoring of harms is more likely to reduce risks (2) as it may capture some harms before or during the data use. If harm is not monitored, the risk to the public is increased, and therefore the public value score is lower (-2).

metadata.feedback: if the data user monitored harm that is (directly or indirectly) caused by their data use

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the ability of the data user to end their activity, once unexpected harms occur? (tick one)
attributes.label: Q22
attributes.explanation: This question aims to understand the data user’s ability to end their activity once unexpected harms occur. For example, if in the course of a medical study it is found that a patient’s data has been leaked, can the study be stopped?
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: A key aspect of harm mitigation is the ability to stop a process if and when harm occurs. If an instance of data use  (e.g., a medical study) cannot be ended immediately when harm occurs, the risk to the public is significantly higher, and therefore the public value score is lower (-3).

choices.body: Harm-causing activity cannot be ended immediately
Harm-causing activity can be ended immediately

metadata.feedback: if it were possible to end the harm-causing activity immediately

attributes.body: Which of the answers below best describe the complaint procedures available to individuals? (tick as many as necessary)
attributes.label: Q23
attributes.explanation: This question aims to capture what complaint procedures are in place for individuals to report harm from data use. For example, if someone were to experience financial harm in the form of being denied a loan on the basis of a predictive algorithm, are they able to submit a complaint to the data user?
attributes.weightingAppendixDescription: Public value is lower when individuals and communities have little or no way to voice their complaint if and when harm occurs(-3). Complaint procedures which are easy to access (1, 2) and from which a prompt response time can be expected (2) receive a higher score, as this implies greater accountability of the data user.

choices.body: Complaint procedure can be initiated online
Complaint procedure designed in an accessible manner

metadata.feedback: if the data user had a complaint procedure regarding their data use in place

attributes.body: What happens with any complaints?
attributes.label: Q24
